column1: THE ART OF PSYCHOLOGICAL WARFARE: 51 PRINCIPLES OF CONFLICT RESOLUTION, NEGOTIATION, STRATEGY, OFFICE POLITICS, CAREER BUILDING, SELF HELP, & MOTIVATION FOR SUCCESS & HAPPINESS IN BUSINESS & LIFE

column4: Annotation
Principle 1: Most aspects of business and life involve never ending psychological battle.
Inevitably, other people's desires come up against our own. There is conflict. There is battle. And that battle is often purely psychological.
In a world of constant transition, there is uncertainty. When there is uncertainty, there is aggression.
Your time, energy, talent, and mental strength are your currency in psychological warfare. Resources such as money just posture you better, but they don't necessarily protect you.
Principle 2: Self-interest rules the world.
Principle 3: The personal paradox: everything is personal, yet nothing is personal.

Business life and personal life are emotionally inseparable. And when people come at you, it's very hard not to take it personally.   The thing to understand is that people pursue their self-interest. They may say things which appear personal, but this is just a tactic to demoralize you so that their self-interest can be advanced.
The master warrior constantly works on and refines his personal psychology so that the actions of others don't cause him to self-destruct as a result of taking attacks personally.
Principle 4: You cannot avoid attack. The world will exploit you.
There are tactics which can deter others from coming after you, but aggression from opponents cannot be completely demolished.
People pursue their self-interest and will take everything from you that they can.
Principle 5: If all is fair in love and war, then the concept of fairness has little to no value.

Forget about fairness. Nothing in business or life is fair. There will likely be no justice for you when you are attacked or exploited. Typically, the most practical reason to play the "fairness" card is as a tactic to shame the opponent, and only if it can help position your self-interest.
Principle 6: Choose your battles carefully.
Just because you are attacked doesn't mean you have to attack back. You do not have the strength to fight every war.

Do not wage psychological war with others just because you can, for that is a waste of energy. Take a deep breath, step back, and carefully think through the cost of going to war and whether the probabilistic payoff is worth the cost.
Remember, your time and energy are your most precious resources in life. Use them wisely.
Principle 7: It is better to die by the sword when you live by the sword.
The trick here is to attack the right people. Attack the opponents who stand in your way and who you believe you can defeat or gain an advantage from.
Principle 8: People are magnificent actors on the stages of business and life; judge them based on their actions, not their words and presentations.
Many people in the world live in self-deceit. This is dangerous because they truly believe they are being sincere when they articulate their supposed good intentions and lack of self-interest.
I'm not saying that you should not trust anyone. Nor am I suggesting that you succumb to paranoia. But I am saying that you should remain vigilant and analytical.
Principle 9: Goal setting is inherently aggressive.
But know that your pursuit of goals, which represent your self-interest, will inevitably collide with the self-interest of others; and then there will be war.
Therefore, any goal you set for yourself will lead to competition with others, which will lead to battle, which will lead to war.
Principle 10: Boldness is a function of tolerance and ambition.
Principle 11: Guard your vulnerabilities; volunteer information conservatively.
There can sometimes be power in stating your vulnerabilities, but this is an advanced gambit indeed and should be reserved for the truly bold.

For the most part, you want to guard your vulnerabilities and devulge only information which would keep your opponents from attacking you. When an opponent knows your vulnerability, they will think long and hard about it, and then attack it fiercely at a moment you least expect it.
Principle 12: Artfully stroke the King's ego.

King (or a Queen) is anyone more powerful than you, regardless of domain: work, social, business, family, etc. Kings seem to exist for the sole purpose of kicking you around. You must learn to artfully stroke their egos.

Point out subtle details to the King in what he is doing, and tell him you are learning a lot from just being around him, and that it is making you a better person. In general, it's better not to compliment the obvious, but to look a little deeper at the details of his behavior and compliment more subtle aspects of it.
Principle 13: Only attack a King with extreme care and deft.
Most often it is wise to play dumb to a King. Impress him only enough that he gives you what you obviously want.
Principle 14: Beware of the ambitious upstart...

Furthermore, the ambitious upstart is dangerous because he is often talented in addition to being bold. He is hot stuff and he knows it. He may, however, have deep insecurities that you can exploit, but proceed with caution.

If you are an ambitious upstart and you piss off a King, he will wait patiently to destroy you. Kings are most concerned and insecure about ambitious upstarts and will destroy them when they can. Remember the value of playing dumb to the King.
Principle 15: Exploit others with grace and care.
Principle 16: Familiarize yourself with the field of battle; avoid fighting the opponent on their turf.
You must know the territory and terrain upon which you will fight the opponent. Knowledge of the terrain is definitely power in warfare.
Principle 17: Consciously drive your neuroses in the direction of rational benign self-interest and self-improvement.
You will know your opponent is driving their neuroses against you when they do something irrational against you.
What you most want to avoid is an opponent's neurotic drive colliding with your neurotic drive, for this means the war has gone nuclear - only a fool engages in nuclear war.
Principle 18: Embrace the reality of passive aggression as it relates to psychological warfare.
Principle 19: Engage in active listening as a means of passive aggression and psychological warfare.
Principle 20: Discover the group your opponent dwells in and attack different factions of the group in unique ways.

This is a very dangerous tactic. Use this tactic at your own risk. The payoff can be huge, but it can also blow up in your face, as you may create new opponents who will be determined and unified in destroying you.
Principle 21: When you aim, you aim to kill.
What I am saying, is that unless you are executing a relatively benign test attack, you should aim to knock your opponent down completely so that they don't attempt another attack on you.
Psychological warfare, like all warfare, is costly. You have nothing to gain by prolonging it. As a general rule, it's best to attack ferociously in hopes that the opponent gives up.
Principle 22: Feign unpredictability and irrationality to your opponent.
Unpredictability and irrationality will often scare the hell out of your opponent, especially if they have something to lose. Therefore, this is often a useful tactic to employ.
Unpredictability is scary because it means that the opponent must continue to stay on guard if they wish to continue attacking you.
Principle 23: Use the power of creative brainstorming to overwhelm the opponent with tactics.
In the heat of battle, opponents can usually only conceive of 2-3 tactics to fight you with.
Do not stop until you have 10 or more feasible tactics, then overwhelm your opponent with the execution of them.
Principle 24: Make up lies about your opponent, but do not stray far from the truth.

You don't have to lie in life. But in some wars, lying can be strategic. When you lie, however, try to stay as close to the truth as possible, for this makes your lies very difficult for your opponent to discredit.

There is a fine line here. You must remain psychologically strong, which means anticipating being attacked without becoming paranoid. If you do become paranoid, then the opponent has won a major psychological battle against you.
Feigning peace is ironically a master tactic when it comes to psychological warfare.
Principle 39: Boldy attack first, but pretend that you are the victim.

Come up with a rationale that makes you look like the victim of your opponent, then boldly attack them. It's best to attack them privately or confidentially, so that others will see you as the victim should the opponent try and attack you back.
Playing the victim card while fiercely attacking the opponent is high art in the world of psychological warfare.
Principle 40: Use bald morality to shame your opponent.
Principle 41: Stay adaptable and agile; maintain an escape route.
When you launch your attacks, it's often useful to have an escape route, so that you can quickly backtrack and retreat if you are confronted with enormous resistance.
Principle 42: Embrace retreat.

it can allow you an opportunity to reflect and regroup, and can sometimes have a psychological deflating effect on the opponent - at just the moment they think that victory is imminent, you retreat and take away that opportunity from them.
Principle 43: Scare your opponent with the unknown.
Principle 44: Champion your self expression in the face of war.
Principle 45: Cut your loses and embrace defeat.
Principle 46: Don't go too far in victory.
You have nothing to gain by rubbing your opponent's nose in defeat, for if you succumb to this urge, you'll allow your own arrogance and narcissism to grow, which can lead to eventual self-defeat.
Be graceful when you are defeated and be graceful when you are victorious.
Principle 47: The only enemy is yourself.
Principle 48: In business and life, you must continually develop your sense of humor, for you will go mad if you are unable to laugh at the absurdity of life's conflicts.
Principle 49: Embrace meditation and prayer.
Principle 50: Love is earned through self growth.
Principle 51: Master yourself.
